'''Ismaïla Sarr''' (born 25 February 1998) is a Senegalese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[EFL Championship]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] and the [[Senegal national football team|Senegal national team]].

==Club career==
===Early career===
Born in [[Saint-Louis, Senegal|Saint-Louis]], Senegal, Sarr started his football career with Senegalese football club [[Génération Foot]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.joueurs.ismaila.sarr.281622.fr.html|title=Football : Ismaïla Sarr|website=footballdatebase.eu|access-date=13 September 2016}}</ref>

===Metz===
On 13 July 2016, Sarr signed his first professional contract with [[FC Metz]] for five years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fcmetz.com/2016-2017/actualites/equipe-pro/ismaila-sarr-sengage-pour-5-ans|title=Ismaïla Sarr s'engage pour 5 ans !|trans-title=Ismaïla Sarr has signed for five seasons.|language=fr|date=13 July 2016|publisher=fcmetz.com}}</ref> He made his league debut on 13 August 2016 against [[Lille OSC]] at [[Stade Saint-Symphorien]], the FC Metz's home ground, which Metz won by 3–2. In this match, he played 20 minutes, after he was substituted for [[Florent Mollet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/08/13/france/ligue-1/fc-de-metz/lille-olympique-sporting-club-metropole/2236765/|title=Metz vs. Lille - 13 August 2016 - Soccerway|website=us.soccerway.com|access-date=13 September 2016}}</ref>

===Stade Rennais===
On 26 July 2017, Sarr signed a four-year contract with [[Ligue 1]] side [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]]. The transfer fee paid to Metz was reported as €17 or 20 million, depending on the source.<ref>{{cite news|title=Transferts : Ismaïla Sarr s'engage officiellement avec Rennes|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Transferts-ismaila-sarr-s-engage-officiellement-avec-rennes/821002|access-date=28 July 2017|work=L'Équipe|date=26 July 2017|language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Okeleji|first1=Oluwashina|title=Senegal's Ismaila Sarr 'rejects Barcelona' for Rennes move|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40739791|access-date=28 July 2017|work=BBC Sport|date=27 July 2017}}</ref> He picked the transfer to Rennes over a move to [[FC Barcelona]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40739791|title=Senegal's Ismaila Sarr 'rejects Barcelona' for Rennes move|date=27 July 2017|work=BBC Sport|access-date=20 January 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>

On 13 December 2018, Sarr scored twice in the second half (including a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]]), as Rennes clinched their place in the [[2018–19 UEFA Europa League]] knockout phase with a (Group K, Matchday 6) 2–0 home win over [[FC Astana]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ligue1.com/autresCompetitions/article/rennes-beat-astana-to-go-through-bordeaux-out.htm|title=Rennes beat Astana to go through, Bordeaux out|publisher=www.ligue1.com|date=13 December 2018|access-date=14 December 2018|archive-date=2 April 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190402204519/https://www.ligue1.com/autresCompetitions/article/rennes-beat-astana-to-go-through-bordeaux-out.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Watford===
On 8 August 2019, Sarr joined [[Premier League]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on a five-year contract. The transfer fee paid to Rennes was a club record for Watford<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sansom |first1=Dan |title=Watford sign Rennes winger Ismaila Sarr for club-record fee |url=https://www.skysports.com/transfer/news/11686/11780227/watford-sign-rennes-winger-ismaila-sarr-for-club-record-fee |website=Sky Sports |access-date=8 August 2019 |date=8 August 2019}}</ref> and reported as "in the region of €30 million.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gray |first1=Ryan |title=Watford have announced the signing of Ismaila Sarr from Rennes |url=https://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/17825048.watford-announced-signing-ismaila-sarr-rennes/ |access-date=8 August 2019 |work=Watford Observer |date=8 August 2019}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Watford in an [[EFL Cup]] tie against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on 27 August 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/49403010 |title=Watford 3-0 Coventry |date=27 August 2019 |publisher=BBC|access-date=27 August 2019}}</ref>

On 29 February 2020, Sarr picked up two goals and an assist in Watford's 3–0 home victory over defending [[UEFA Champions League]] winners [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], handing them their first defeat of the [[2019–20 Premier League|2019–20 season]] and ending the club's 44-match unbeaten league run.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mott |first1=Ryan |title=Watford beat Liverpool to end 27-match unbeaten run|url=https://onefootball.com/en/news/4-points-as-watford-beat-liverpool-to-end-27-match-unbeaten-run-29310791?variable=20200229 |website=OneFootball |access-date=29 February 2020}}</ref>

On 24 April 2021, Sarr scored from the penalty spot in [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]’s 1–0 home win over [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]], sealing Watford’s return to the [[Premier League]] after one season.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/56781828|title=Watford 1–0 Millwall|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Rob|last=Stevens|date=24 April 2021|access-date=26 April 2021}}</ref>
Sarr ended as [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]’s top scorer for the [[2020–21 Watford F.C. season|2020–21]] season, scoring thirteen goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fbref.com/en/squads/2abfe087/Watford-Stats|title=2020-21 Watford Stats, Championship|website=FBref.com|access-date=8 July 2021}}</ref>

He continued from where he left off as he scored in [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]'s 3–2 win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in their opening game of the [[2021–22 Premier League]] season.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Watford vs Aston Villa LIVE!|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/watford-vs-aston-villa/live/446297|access-date=14 August 2021|website=Sky Sports|language=en}}</ref>

==International career==
Sarr has represented his country with the [[Senegal national under-23 football team|Senegal U23 national team]]. In 2015, he played in [[2015 Africa U-23 Cup of Nations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://admin.cafonline.com/en-us/competitions/u-23africacupofnations/TeamDetails/PlayerDetails?CompetitionPlayerID=TyclG%2buS5J7c5OqznR%2bEhdZu%2fb3eociUa2h4Iv5tEJb9CkL0pV%2b03HGH78dFKci6&TeamsIDs=UiTW21Mwh%2fVESS8j4UPYKrntTXWGBMcsS6Z79ys00T1naAfw2hHLclMNlld99jQi|title=CAF - Competitions - U-23 Africa Cup of Nations - Team Details - Player Details - Ismaïla Sarr|website=cafonline.com|access-date=13 September 2016}}</ref> At that time, his age was only 17. He contributed that Senegal finished the competition in a fourth place, playing three games.

He played for the first time with [[Senegal national football team|Senegal national team]] for a match against [[Namibia national football team|Namibia]] in September 2016 in [[Dakar]] (2–0) for [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification]], for which Senegal had already qualified. As a symbol, he came into play in the 67th minute in place of the former resident of [[Génération Foot]] and [[FC Metz|Metz]], [[Sadio Mané]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Senegal-premiere-convocation-pour-le-jeune-attaquant-de-metz-ismaila-sarr/717979|title=Sénégal : première convocation pour le jeune attaquant de Metz Ismaïla Sarr|website=lequipe.fr|access-date=17 August 2016}}</ref> On 8 January 2017, Sarr scored his first international goal in a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] against [[Libya national football team|Libya]] in [[Stade Municipal de Kintélé]], [[Brazzaville]].

In May 2018, he was named in Senegal's 23-man squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Crawford |first1=Stephen |title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - Final 23-man lists |url=https://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb |website=Goal |access-date=16 July 2019 |date=4 June 2018}}</ref>

In [[2019 Africa Cup of Nations|2019]], Sarr was part of the Senegal squad that reached the final of the [[Africa Cup of Nations]], for only the second time in the nation's history.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/sport/senegal-algeria-set-rematch-afcon-final|title=Senegal, Algeria set for rematch in Afcon final|publisher=eNCA|access-date=20 July 2019}}</ref> He played the full 90 minutes of the final on 19 July 2019, as they lost 1–0 to [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jul/19/senegal-algeria-africa-cup-of-nations-final-match-report|title=Algeria claim second Afcon title after Bounedjah's lucky strike sinks Senegal|website=theguardian.com|publisher=Guardian News & Media Limited|date=19 July 2019|access-date=19 July 2019}}</ref>

In November 2019, he suffered an ankle injury whilst on international duty.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/50446186|title=2021 Africa Cup of Nations: Senegal await Ismaila Sarr injury verdict|work=BBC Sport |date=16 November 2019}}</ref>

Sarr was part of [[2021 Africa Cup of Nations squads#Senegal|Senegal's squad]] for the [[2021 Africa Cup of Nations]]; the Lions of Teranga went on to win the tournament for the first time in their history.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cafonline.com/total-africa-cup-of-nations/news/cisse-unveils-senegal-squad-hopes-for-elusive-totalenergies-afcon-title|title=Cisse unveils Senegal squad, hopes for elusive TotalEnergies AFCON title|publisher=[[Confederation of African Football]]|date=25 December 2021|access-date=28 March 2023|archive-date=9 January 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220109145849/https://www.cafonline.com/total-africa-cup-of-nations/news/cisse-unveils-senegal-squad-hopes-for-elusive-totalenergies-afcon-title|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Senegal 0-0 Egypt |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/60186276 |website=[[BBC Sport]] |access-date=28 March 2023 |date=7 February 2022}}</ref>

He was appointed a [[National Order of the Lion|Grand Officer of the National Order of the Lion]] by [[President of Senegal]] [[Macky Sall]] following the nation's victory at the tournament.<ref name= "reuters">{{cite web |title=Cash prizes, real estate, and highest honours as Senegal celebrates Nations Cup heroes |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/cash-prizes-real-estate-highest-honours-senegal-celebrates-nations-cup-heroes-2022-02-08/ |website=[[Reuters]] |access-date=28 March 2023 |date=8 February 2022}}</ref>

==Honours==
'''Rennes'''
* [[Coupe de France]]: [[2018–19 Coupe de France|2018–19]]<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/48071397
|title =Rennes 2 PSG 2 (6-5 on penalties)|date=29 April 2019|work=BBC Sport|access-date=30 April 2019}}</ref>

'''Senegal'''
* [[Africa Cup of Nations|African Cup of Nations]]: [[2021 Africa Cup of Nations|2021]];<ref>{{Cite news|date=5 February 2022|title=Africa Cup of Nations final: Mane with winning penalty as Senegal beat Egypt on penalties|language=en-GB|work=BBC Sport|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/59408846|access-date=6 February 2022}}</ref> runner-up: [[2019 Africa Cup of Nations|2019]]<ref>{{Cite news|title=Algeria win Africa Cup of Nations|language=en-GB|work=BBC Sport|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/48959714|access-date=6 February 2022}}</ref>

'''Individual'''
* [[UEFA Europa League]] Goal of the Season: [[2018–19 UEFA Europa League|2018–19]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Top Ten Goals of the 2018/19 UEFA Europa League|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=2606256.html |website=UEFA.com |publisher=Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) |date=30 May 2019 |access-date=4 June 2019}}</ref>

'''Orders'''
*[[National Order of the Lion|Grand Officer of the National Order of the Lion]]: 2022<ref name="reuters" />
